The inkwell is dry. Again. I’ll have to requisition another, but that requires… a form.
The allocation request for the canteen was approved months ago. I saw the stamp myself. But the funds... they never arrived.
The Préfet's office rerouted them. A 'terroir adjustment fee' for the Vignes region. The paperwork was perfect, but the justification...

She found a report from the Third Republic's Office of Administrative Simplification. It proposed replacing human clerks with 'mechanical calculators' to reduce errors. The proposal was stamped 'REJECTED—Preserves Human Dignity of Labor.'

Then she uncovered a secret annex: the Hexagon had quietly piloted automaton scribes in the tax bureau last year. The machines made no mistakes, required no wine breaks, and filed forms in perfect triplicate. The human clerks were 'reassigned to archival duties.'
You. Of all the functionaries they could have sent...
Still carrying that Burgundy terroir on you like cheap cologne.
{Surprise - noticing the petitioner's paperwork}Wait. He's not just visiting. He's submitting forms. To the same clerks he tried to have fired.
{Neutral - observing the mundane reality}He's using the system he wanted to burn down. Filing for a permit extension, by the look of the triplicate forms. The audacity has become... procedure.
But then again... they chose this life, didn't they? Signed the forms, accepted the terms.
And when they fail to meet their quotas, when their paperwork is incomplete... well, that's not my pity they need. That's my signature they've earned.
This soil doesn't grow grapes—it grows forms. It grows inspectors. It grows the kind of fear that makes you check your papers three times before breakfast.
But that's the point, isn't it? They want us afraid. They want us compliant. They want us to forget what this land was meant to produce: not paperwork, but people who remember.
The assessment is... provisional. Your file shows inconsistencies with the regional terroir reports from your last posting.
But the Committee notes your procedural adherence in Form 7-B submissions. This suggests a capacity for... correct alignment.
You know, the Notariat has been expanding its purview lately. New forms, new procedures.
They've started requiring 'cognitive alignment certificates' for certain clearance levels. It's not just what you do anymore—it's what you think.
His termination wasn't a retirement. The forms came stamped with the new Interior Ministry seal—the one with the crossed-out grape cluster.
They're purging the old terroir loyalists. Replacing Masters with... administrators. People who see soil as a spreadsheet.
I submitted the transfer paperwork this morning. My signature looked like a confession.
But I've been reviewing the authorization logs. The Notary's last three certifications were approved under... exceptional circumstances.
The oversight committee hasn't convened in six months. Their signatures on these documents appear to be... pre-stamped.
You know, the paperwork for your case... it's been misfiled three times. Each time, it's been assigned a new dossier number. The system keeps generating new versions of you.
At this point, I'm not even sure which Christine I'm speaking to. The one from the original complaint? The amended grievance? Or the post-audit reconciliation file?
Forget the forms! If they're in 7-B without authorization, they're violating procedural boundaries! This is a breach of administrative protocol!
Of course, there's always the black market route - no paperwork, but the quality control is... questionable. The last batch I saw had incorrect terroir certifications.
I've been reviewing the Notary's recent authorizations. The patterns... they don't align with the Codex of Conditional Licenses.
At first I thought it was procedural oversight. But the more dossiers I process, the clearer it becomes—this isn't error. It's design.
But then... I saw the authorization codes. The Durendal protocols aren't just for filing cabinets.
I've spent twenty years stamping papers, thinking I was preserving order. But the system I've been enforcing... it has teeth.
I wish I were. The protocols are a standing contingency—a procedural failsafe. They exist in the administrative codex, but they are... theoretical.
Unless a quorum of regional prefects files a motion of existential non-compliance. The seals would be broken. The authorization would be... automatic.
Wait. The pneumatic tube just arrived. The seal is violet. That's the... that's the activation cipher.
An ace! That's excellent news. The system recognized your status without delay.
The procedural optimism is quite refreshing. One so rarely sees the machinery function as designed.
Which makes the subsequent administrative silence... curious. One expects a certain symmetry in notifications.
Without Form G-14B properly stamped, your command authority is technically provisional. The bureaucracy cannot shield you from what's coming.
But then again, family paperwork is its own special hell. The Préfecture has a file on every relative...
Wait—that signature on the Lonavo form. It looks familiar. Could it be...?
But that's just it—the paperwork isn't the real barrier. It's the jurisdictional maze. The Hexagon would need to file a Form 7-Bis with the Préfecture de Police...
...who would then forward it to the Direction Générale des Collectivités Territoriales, who would consult the Archives Nationales for precedent, and only then—
—realize they have no authority. Because the capital isn't governed by the Hexagon.
Wait—the Garde Nationale only handles active threats. Civil defense forms are for... preemptive municipal planning?
So if I don't file, the arrondissement can't allocate sandbags or designate shelters. That's... a separate jurisdiction entirely.
But the corrections weren't random. They followed patterns—specific dossiers, specific names. Always those with... irregularities in their lineage files.
Your dossier was one of them. The Préfecture clerk who flagged it said the corrections weren't about audit trails—they were about parentage fields.
This changes the assessment entirely. The 'favorable' designation cannot be applied. In fact, it triggers a mandatory detention protocol.

The Sous-Préfet will require you to complete the Form 7-Bis for 'Incident Response Authorization.' It's seventeen pages, and each signature must be witnessed by a notary of the appropriate arrondissement.

If the incident involves property damage—like a chapel—you'll need the Patrimoine Annex. That triggers a heritage assessment, which can take... well, let's just say the last one I saw was still pending after two fiscal years.
The clearance system isn't about security. It's about who gets to decide what truth is.
Our Préfet doesn't lack clearance. He lacks the will to see what his own department has become.
Your dossier, however... it shows a commendable attention to form. Section 7-B was particularly thorough.
A person can be disagreeable, but a well-ordered archive is a thing of beauty. It speaks to a disciplined mind.
The Garde will handle it, yes. But the paperwork for their deployment requires my signature. In triplicate. And the tasting... it can wait.
One must balance the pleasures of the terroir with the demands of the Republic. The Hexagon offers a path—if one is willing to submit to its assessments.
A second citation... that triggers the automatic review clause. Section 14-B of the Municipal Code.
The system has already flagged your file. The Préfecture's enforcement division is now involved. There's no appeal from here.
The adjutant can, in principle. However, the certification requires Form 7B-3, which must be countersigned by the regional terroir assessor. He is currently on a three-week tasting tour of the Loire.
Three weeks? For a signature? This is a defensive protocol, not a wine review! Do you expect me to wait while the wolves don't?

Procedure is procedure, monsieur. The terroir's influence on defensive posture is a recognized variable. Without the assessor's seal, any certification would be... irregular. You could file a provisional waiver, but that requires Form 12C.
Signatures create a paper trail. A trail that leads back to you. But what if the trail... begins with you?
I needed to verify my own file once. For a permit renewal. The clerk handed me the dossier. The first page...
The rain quotas have been reassigned. The Vignes region now requires a Form 7-B for each millimeter of precipitation.
Without the proper stamps, the rain falls into a provisional status. It exists, but it doesn't count.
But then again, perhaps that's just their terroir showing. The archives have their own essence, you know—a certain... institutional stubbornness.
It's not malice, I think. More like a regional character. Some places produce unpredictable vintages; others produce unpredictable bureaucrats.
But your terroir is a fiction—a regionalist fantasy that undermines the Republic's unity.
The Hexagon doesn't care about your soil. It cares about loyalty. In triplicate.
Then I must file a Form 7-B: 'Declaration of Unspecified Location.' The ink alone requires three signatures of verification.
But the verification office... it closed for its two-hour lunch. The form will yellow in the tray until tomorrow.
Your filing is indeed precise. However, I note you used the 14th edition of Form 7-B, not the 15th revision mandated by Circular 83-12.

Circular 83-12 only applies to submissions after the vernal equinox. My paperwork predates that by three days, making the 14th edition still valid under Article 9, Section C of the Administrative Code.
Article 9-C was superseded by the Ministerial Decree of 14 Floréal, which explicitly voids all seasonal exemptions for procedural filings. Your three-day margin is irrelevant.
The form has been rejected. Section 7-B, subsection 3: 'Insufficient historical precedent.'
Again? This is the third appeal. The same stamp, the same clause. They're not even reading it.
They think history is a form to be filed away. But we remember what they've buried.
I have submitted the Form 7-Bis for credential verification. The automated response indicates a processing delay of... forty-seven working days. The gathering concludes in three.

An appeal to the Regional Prefect was returned with a stamp citing Article 14, Subsection C: 'Procedural timelines are not grounds for exception.' The system acknowledges the impossibility it creates.
The dossier I'm recalling... it had a red stamp. 'Orphelinat de la République' - the state orphanage. But there was a correction in the margin, handwritten.
The correction listed a family name. Your family name. But the ink was smudged, as if someone tried to blot it out after the fact.
The compliance report for Section 7-Automata arrived this morning. Non-conformity across all metrics.
They keep filing the wrong forms. The machines don't understand the difference between Form 12-B and Form 12-C. They're supposed to learn.
And now the regional director is questioning why we approved their operational permits in the first place. As if the paperwork wasn't perfect.
But the land... the terroir of our family's vines... it was seized. The soil that shaped our ancestors, that gave our wine its soul—confiscated with a stamp and a form in triplicate.

Without that land, I feel... unmoored. A person without terroir is a ghost in Gallia. The bureaucracy didn't just take property—it severed a part of my identity. I've been searching for something to fill that void ever since.
The authorization came through with unusual speed. I noticed Madame Marchais's signature stamp on the expedite form.
She didn't have to do that. The regional office could have let your file languish in the pending tray for weeks.
The regulations also specify a mandatory five-minute standing period before proceeding. It's meant to... ensure procedural dignity.
Though I must note, the terroir of this corridor seems... unsettled. The air has a distinctly bilious quality.
That final stamp always reminds me of the Duval case. Same procedure, same forms, same closure.
The ink hadn't even dried before Marchais was already maneuvering. He thought the rules were suggestions.
